conclusion: Determine the magnitude and direction of the force exerted by the small ball on the light rod at the highest point P.
At the highest point P, the ball is moving horizontally.
Forces acting on the ball at the highest point P are gravitational force (mg) downward and tension force (F) upward.
Net force provides the centripetal force required for circular motion.
The ball is initially at the lowest point with an upward velocity v0 = 4 m/s.
Using conservation of mechanical energy to calculate the velocity of the ball at the highest point P.
Initial energy at the lowest point is E_initial = 8 J.
Final energy at the highest point is E_final = 0.5mv_P^2 + mgh.
Solving gives v_P^2 = 6, so v_P = sqrt(6) m/s.
Velocity of the ball at the highest point is v_P = sqrt(6) m/s.
Net force acting on the ball provides the centripetal force: F_net = F - mg = mv_P^2/L.
Substitute values to find F - 10 = 12, so F = 22 N.
Force exerted by the ball on the rod is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to the tension force F.
Since F acts vertically upward, the force exerted by the ball on the rod is vertically downward.
Magnitude of the force exerted by the ball on the light rod is 22 N.
Direction of the force is vertically downward.
